questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intraoperative findings for treatment of large bowel obstruction is incorrect?

choices.text: A distended caecum during laparotomy indicates a large bowel obstruction.
Emergency caecostomy can be done to stabilize the patient.
A collapsed caecum during laparotomy suggests a large bowel obstruction.
Resection and anastomosis are appropriate treatments for Crohn's disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A collapsed caecum during laparotomy suggests a large bowel obstruction.

 

Explanation:

 

A collapsed caecum indicates that the obstruction is in the small bowel. In contrast, a distended caecum is indicative of a large bowel obstruction.

Management of Large Bowel Obstruction:

  • Surgical Management:
    • Malignant Lesions:
      • Resectable Lesions: Perform emergency right hemicolectomy with primary anastomosis if the patient's condition allows.
      • Non-Resectable Lesions: Consider proximal stoma (colostomy or ileostomy) or ileo-transverse bypass.
    • Splenic Flexure Obstruction: Extended right hemicolectomy with ileo-descending anastomosis.
    • Left Colon or Rectosigmoid Junction Obstruction: Immediate resection unless contraindicated.
  • Emergency Procedures:
    • Imminent Perforation: Perform emergency caecostomy or loop colostomy/ileostomy to stabilize the patient. (Option B)
  • Intraoperative Considerations:
    • Colostomy: Often performed if the distal bowel cannot be closed; Hartmann’s procedure if the distal bowel is not suitable for closure.
    • Anastomosis: Consider using proximal colon if feasible, with on-table colonic lavage for decompression and cleaning.
  • Palliative and Preoperative Stenting:
    • Self-Expanding Metal Stent: Preferred in palliative care.
    • Stenting as a Bridge to Surgery: Recommended for potentially curable left-sided colon cancer.
  • Alternative to Stenting:
    • Decompressing Stoma: If colonic stenting is not feasible
  • Adhesions: Perform adhesiolysis.
  • Malignancy: Resection and anastomosis (for peritoneal carcinomatosis)
  • Hernia: Perform reduction
  • Crohn's Disease: Resection and anastomosis (Option D)

Laparotomy Findings:

  • Distended Caecum: Indicates large bowel obstruction. (Option A)
  • Collapsed Caecum: Indicates small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of previous abdominal surgeries presents with severe abdominal pain that initially started as crampy but has become constant and steady. The patient has a temperature of 102 degrees, 128 beats per minute heart rate, and elevated white blood cell count. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate for confirming in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CECT

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of strangulating obstruction, characterized by constant, steady pain, fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count. Given the patient’s history of previous abdominal surgeries, there is a risk of adhesions leading to strangulation.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this condition, as it provides detailed images that help identify bowel ischemia and assess vascular compromise effectively.

Simple obstruction and Strangulating obstruction

Feature

Simple Obstruction

Strangulating Obstruction

Definition

Mechanical obstruction with intact blood supply.

Mechanical obstruction with compromised blood supply.

Pain

Crampy, colicky pain.

Constant, steady pain.

Systemic Symptoms

Typically absent or mild.

Fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count.

Diagnostic Tests

Abdominal X-ray (initial assessment).

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT).

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) for detailed evaluation.

Additional Features

Usually no systemic signs of infection or inflammation.

Systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever) and inflammation.

Management

Can be managed with conservative treatment or surgery if necessary.

Requires urgent surgical intervention to address ischemia and restore blood flow.

 

Abdominal X-ray(Option A): Not sufficient for confirming strangulation or assessing bowel ischemia.

USG abdomen(Option C): Less effective at detecting detailed features of strangulation.

 

MRI abdomen(Option D): Not the first choice for diagnosing bowel obstructions or strangulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with a history of abdominal surgery performed 3 days ago. She reports worsening abdominal distension and has not passed stool since the surgery. On examination her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

 

Explanation:

  • This presentation is consistent with paralytic ileus, a condition where impaired peristaltic activity results in decreased bowel motility.
  • The absence of bowel sounds and abdominal distension, combined with a history of recent abdominal surgery, supports this diagnosis.
  • An abdominal X-ray typically reveals dilated bowel loops and multiple air-fluid levels, which are characteristic findings in paralytic ileus.

 

Paralytic Ileus

  • Characterized by:
    • Impaired intestinal motility due to failure of peristaltic wave transmission.
    • Collection of food and fluid in the bowel (Option A).
    • Abdominal distension.
  • Type: Adynamic obstruction.

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia) (Option D).
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Pathophysiology
  • Neurogenic- enteric nervous system and CNS
  • Inflammatory- histamine, IL-6 and IL-8, monocytes and macrophages
  • Enteric hormones and neuropeptides- motilin, substance P, and vasoactive intestinal peptide [VIP]
  • Perioperative electrolyte disturbances
  • Opioids
  • Duration of surgery and extent of surgical trauma

Clinical Features
  • Abdominal distension.
  • Abdominal discomfort.
  • Non-colicky pain.
  • Vomiting.
  • Non-passage of feces and flatus.
  • Absence of bowel sounds.

Investigations

IOC: Abdominal X-ray. (Option C)

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

Management

Decompression: Nasogastric aspiration.

 

Diet: Restrict oral intake until bowel sounds return or the patient starts passing feces and flatus.

 

Treatment of Underlying Cause:

  • Correct dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia).
  • Discontinue medications affecting motility (e.g., opiates).

 

Surgery is the first-line treatment (Option B): The first-line treatment is usually conservative (e.g., nasogastric tube, restricting oral intake).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought with intermittent episodes of severe abdominal pain, during which he pulls his knees to his chest and cries inconsolably. He passed a small amount of "red, jelly-like" stool. On examination, the child appears pale, lethargic, and mildly dehydrated. What is the most likely abdominal CT finding seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Target sign

Explanation:

  • Intussusception is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario
  • Presents most commonly in children with episodic abdominal pain, lethargy, vomiting, and "red currant jelly" stools
  • Target sign is seen in the CT abdomen due to telescoping of one segment of the bowel into another

 

Intussusception:

  • It is telescoping of one segment of the bowel into another
  • Most common age group- 5 to 10 months of age
  • Most common type in adults is colo-colic. Lead point is usually meckel’s diverticulum, polyp, malignancy etc.
  • Most common type in children is ileocolic. No lead point generally.

 

Parts of Intussusception:

 

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Colicky pain
  • Episodes of crying, vomiting (bilious), and drawing up of the legs to the chest
  • The attacks last for a few minutes
  • In between the attacks, the child is asymptomatic
  • Stool mixed with blood and mucus - ‘redcurrant jelly’ stool
  • On rectal examination, blood-stained mucus may be found on the finger
  • On per abdomen examination:
    • Sausage-shaped lump with concavity towards the umbilicus
    • Emptiness in right iliac fossa- the sign of Dance

 

Investigations: USG is the IOC in children and CECT is the IOC in adults.

Barium enema:

  • Claw sign (Option B)

  • Coiled spring sign (Option C)

Ultrasound/CT:

  • Target /donut/ bull’s eye sign- transverse view (Option A)

  • Pseudokidney sign- longitudinal view


X-ray abdomen:

Multiple air-fluid levels suggestive of bowel obstruction

 

Treatment:

  • Resuscitation with intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics and nasogastric drainage
  • Air or barium enema reduction
  • Surgical reduction if radiological reduction fails
  • Resection and primary anastomosis in irreducible intussusception

 

Coffee bean sign (Option D): It is seen on an X-ray abdomen in a case of sigmoid volvulus.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient, bedridden after hip surgery, presents with a 4-day history of progressive abdominal distension, nausea, and constipation. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended but non-tender, with decreased bowel sounds. An abdominal X-ray shows dilated loops of colon, particularly in the cecum, but no air-fluid levels or evidence of mechanical obstruction. His vital signs are stable, and there is no fever. Which of the following drugs is commonly used in pharmacologic treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neostigmine

 

Explanation:

  • Neostigmine is a parasympathomimetic drug, which is the preferred treatment in colonic pseudo-obstruction
  • It causes strong colonic peristalsis that usually leads to subsequent flatus and bowel movements

 

Colonic Pseudo-Obstruction (Ogilvie’s syndrome):

It is massive dilatation of the colon with obstructive symptoms but in the absence of mechanical obstruction.

 

Risk factors:

  • Frailty and senility
    • Neurological
    • Neurodegenerative diseases
    • Stroke
    • Spinal cord injury
    • Retroperitoneum tumour infiltration
  • Trauma/Surgical
    • Major orthopaedic injuries or surgery involving vertebral, pelvic, and femoral
    • Major gynaecological surgery
    • Obstetrics, including caesarean section
  • Systemic inflammation due to sepsis, trauma, multiorgan failure
  • Localised infections in the respiratory system, urinary tract
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Metabolic and electrolyte disturbances
  • Medications like opioids and any with anticholinergic actions (e.g. psychiatric and Parkinson’s), calcium channel antagonists

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Abdominal distension, discomfort
  • Tympanic percussion, sluggish bowel sounds, and non-tender

 

Investigations:

  • X-ray abdomen: Colonic dilatation
  • Definitive investigation- CT

Treatment:

  • Correction of risk factors:
    • Correct fluid and electrolyte imbalance factors
    • Stop offending drugs like opioids, anticholinergics, and calcium channel blockers
    • Empty the rectum by enemas and/or flatus tube
  • Endoscopic decompression:
    • Colonoscopy +/– flatus tube
  • Pharmacological treatment:
    • Intravenous neostigmine (Option B)
    • Contraindicated in:
      • Arrhythmia
      • Bronchospasm
  • Surgery:
    • Subtotal colectomy with ileostomy


 

Stimulant laxatives (Option C) and osmotic laxatives (Option D): They should be avoided as they can worsen colonic dilation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a 2-day history of progressive abdominal distension, constipation, and colicky pain. He has a history of chronic constipation and has been bedridden for the past few months due to a hip fracture. On examination, his abdomen is distended and tympanic, with mild tenderness. Abdominal guarding and rigidity not observed. X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Which of the following factors does not predispose to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Short pelvic mesocolon

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the clinical presentation and coffee bean sign in the X-ray abdomen, the most probable diagnosis is sigmoid volvulus
  • Long pelvic mesocolon allows the sigmoid colon to move excessively, predisposing it to twist upon its own mesenteric axis causing sigmoid volvulus.

 

Sigmoid volvulus:

It is the twist (rotation) in the axis of the loop of the bowel

 

Predisposing factors:

  • High-residue diet
  • Elderly patients with chronic constipation (Option A ruled out)
  • Chronic psychotropic drug
  • Anticholinergic drugs (Option B ruled out)
  • Mentally-retarded individuals (Option C ruled out)
  • Adhesions; Peridiverticulitis
  • Overloaded redundant pelvic colon
  • Long pelvic mesocolon (Option D)
  • Narrow attachment of sigmoid mesocolon

 

Clinical features:

  • It causes closed-loop obstruction
  • Large bowel obstruction:
  • Colicky pain
  • Abdominal distension
  • Absolute constipation or obstipation
  • Vomiting

 

Investigations:

  • Plain X-ray
    • omega sign- single grossly distended loop of colon arising out of the pelvis and extending towards the diaphragm.
    • Coffee-bean sign or Bent-inner tube sign

  • Contrast enema:
    • Bird's beak sign (ace of spades appearance)- Upper end of the barium column tapers into the spirally twisted distal sigmoid colon.

 

 

  • Others: CT

 

Treatment:

Procedure

Indication

Sigmoidoscopic derotation

Initial treatment for sigmoid volvulus

Sigmoidopexy

Prevention of recurrence in non-emergent cases

Elective sigmoid colectomy

Prevention of recurrence in patients with recurrent volvulus

Hartmann’s procedure

Cases of gangrene or perforation(peritonitis)

questions.text: Which of the following options is not true regarding caecal volvulus?

choices.text: Rotation is more commonly seen in clockwise direction
Caecal volvulus involves the terminal ileum and the right colon
In caecal bascule, there is axial twisting
Clinically, it may manifest as small bowel obstruction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) In caecal bascule, there is axial twisting

 

Explanation:

The caecal bascule is the upward folding of the caecum and there is no axial twisting

 

Caecal volvulus:

  • Caecum, terminal ileum, and right colon are involved in the volvulus (Option B ruled out)
  • Caecal bascule is the upward folding of the cecum anteriorly and there is no axial twisting. Only caecum is involved in this.
  • Rotation is more commonly clockwise (Option A ruled out)

Clinical features:

  • Since the ileum is involved, patients have signs and symptoms of small bowel obstruction (Option D ruled out)
    • Colicky pain
    • Multiple episodes of bilious vomiting
    • Obstipation
  • Ischaemia is common

 

Investigations:

  • X-ray of the abdomen shows caecal dilatation, a single air-fluid level, small bowel dilatation, and absence of gas in the distal colon
  • Others: Barium enema and CT

 

Treatment:

  • Surgical reduction
  • Caecopexy
  • Ileocolic resection and ileocolic anastomosis or ileostomy

questions.text: Which of the following is/are components of Hartmann’s procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation: Components of Hartmann’s procedure are rectosigmoid resection, closure of the rectal stump, and formation of an end colostomy.

 

Hartmann’s procedure:

  • Developed due to high rates of anastomotic failure and mortality following resection and primary anastomosis in obstructing left-sided colonic carcinoma
  • In elderly people, anastomosis is not preferred during an emergency
  • Hence, instead of performing anastomosis, we go for Hartman's procedure to manage Sigmoidectomy in the elderly
  • It is usually followed by subsequent re-anastomosis

 

Components:

  • Rectosigmoid resection
  • Closure of the rectal stump
  • Formation of an end colostomy

Indications:

Obstruction or perforation of the left colon due to:

  • Malignancy
  • Diverticulitis
  • Ischemia
  • Volvulus
  • Trauma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of abdominal surgery presents with severe crampy abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. On examination, his abdomen is distended, and he has not had a bowel movement for three days. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pelvic Adhesions

 

Explanation:

The patient shows symptoms of small bowel obstruction, including severe crampy abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and constipation. Most likely due to pelvic adhesions, often a result of previous abdominal surgery.

 

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

 

Causes
  • Adhesions (Option A) (Most common)
  • Malignancy
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • Hernia
  • Crohn's Disease
  • Tb
  • PID
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Cancer

Surgeries with High Risk of Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)
  • Pelvic surgeries (Highest risk)
  • Lower abdominal surgeries
  • Upper abdominal surgeries

Malignancies Responsible for SBO
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis

 

Clinical Features of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Colicky Abdominal Pain (First symptom):
    • Due to hyperperistalsis in the small intestine caused by intestinal obstruction.
  • Multiple Episodes of Bilious Vomiting
  • Obstipation (Absolute Constipation)
  • Proximal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Vomiting
    • Dyselectrolytemia (electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting)
  • Distal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Distension (more prominent)

Colorectal Cancer (Option B): Less likely as there is a history of previous abdominal surgery. Also, bilious vomiting is indicative of upper GI pathology, not Colon

Inguinal Hernia (Option C): presents with localized groin pain and a palpable hernia.

Crohn's Disease (Option D): Usually presents with a chronic course and additional symptoms like diarrhea or weight loss, which are not mentioned here.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with acute abdominal pain, and bilious vomiting. Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen, and he has not had a bowel movement for three days. An abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start IV fluids (RL)

 

Explanation:

The patient’s presentation of acute abdominal pain, distension, and bilious vomiting, along with the abdominal X-ray findings showing dilated bowel loops and valvulae conniventes, confirms the diagnosis of small bowel obstruction (SBO). The best initial step is to start IV fluids (RL).

 

Investigations for Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Diagnostic Test: Abdominal X-ray
    • Erect View:
      • Better for identifying air-fluid levels.
      • Shows dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels in a step-ladder pattern.

  • Supine View:
    • Better for identifying the site of obstruction.
    • Obstruction typically visible in the ileum.
  • IOC-CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography):
    • Used for:
      • High-grade obstruction.
      • Extraluminal causes of obstruction.
      • Strangulation.

Radiographic Features

Jejunum

Plicae circulares or valvulae conniventes

  • Visible as circumferential, ring-like patterns.
  • Multiple dilated bowel loops.
  • Loops are centrally located.
  • The mucosal pattern appears well-defined with a “feathery” appearance due to the plicae circulares.

Ileum

Dilated bowel loops.

  • Loops are centrally located.
  • Featureless or “characteristically characterless” appearance, lacking the pronounced mucosal pattern seen in the jejunum.

 

Management of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Initial Steps:
    • NIL per oral
    • Insert 2 large-bore IV cannulas.
    • Start IV fluids. (Option B)
      • Fluid of choice: Ringer's lactate.
  • Proximal Decompression with nasogastric aspiration
  • Monitoring, including urine output, and supportive treatment

Administer oral laxatives (Option A): Contraindicated in SBO as they can worsen the obstruction by increasing bowel movement without addressing the underlying issue.

Exploratory laparotomy (Option C): it is reserved for cases where conservative management fails or if there is evidence of complications such as strangulation.

IV Prokinetics (Option D): Prokinetics are contraindicated in case of small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Based on the findings visible in the X-ray, all of the following are true, except:

choices.text: Haustral folds are irregularly spaced and do not span the full diameter
Supine view shows centrally positioned dilated bowel loops without haustrations
Upright view reveals multiple air-fluid levels in a step ladder pattern
Haustral folds lack indentations opposite one another

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Supine view shows centrally positioned dilated bowel loops without haustrations.

 

Explanation:

  • The given x-ray shows large bowel obstruction.
  • Dilated bowel loops on the supine view are typically positioned peripherally, with haustrations.

 

Large Bowel X-ray Findings:

Supine View:

  • Dilated bowel loops
  • Positioned peripherally
  • Haustrations present
  • Wider in calibre

Upright View: (Option C)

  • Dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels
  • Step ladder pattern

Additional Information:

  • Large bowel (except for the cecum) shows haustral folds
  • Haustral folds:
    • Spaced irregularly (Option A)
    • Do not cross the whole diameter of the bowel
    • Do not have indentations placed opposite one another (Option D)
